title: 104_s1215
content:
The "Neighborhood Security Act" aims to establish demonstration projects to test the effectiveness of community residents working with local police to prevent violent crime and drug trafficking, boost economic development, and stop retaliation against residents involved in these activities. The "Neighborhood Security Act" authorizes the Secretary to award annual grants for 4 years, ranging from $25,000 to $100,000. Grant amounts may be reduced based on appropriations, and unused funds will be redistributed or repaid to the Treasury. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a qualified entity must submit an application to the Secretary within 12 months of enactment. The application must include an agreement with the local police department, a coordination plan, and a community development strategy. The Secretary will consider various criteria when approving applications for grants under this Act, including supporting community economic development, participant's track record, project administration, coordination abilities, and plans to prevent crime and drug trafficking. The Secretary will evaluate grant applications based on criteria such as community involvement, coordination with local police to prevent crime, consistency with eligible activities, funding sources, information sharing for evaluation, and other relevant factors. Applicants showing commitment to working with project participants will receive preference. The Secretary will approve or disapprove grant applications within 15 months based on criteria like community involvement, coordination with local police, and economic development capabilities in designated areas with high crime rates. SEC. 5. ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES. Activities funded by grants under this Act include citizen patrols to prevent crime, block watch activities for surveillance and evidence protection, and property modification programs to enhance security. Activities funded by grants under this Act may include changes like constructing fences in parks or buildings to prevent criminal activity, squatter eviction programs, expanding community liaisons with police, developing programs to prevent retaliation, and other related activities. Additionally, grant funds can be used for further support activities. The activities funded by grants under this Act may include purchasing equipment and supplies like cameras, video cameras, walkie-talkies, and computers, training project participants, and hiring staff to assist in coordinating activities among project participants and with the local police department. SEC. 6. LOCAL CONTROL OVER PROJECTS. Each organization conducting a demonstration project under this Act has exclusive authority over project administration. The Secretary may issue regulations to ensure compliance with approved applications and the Act. SEC. 7. MONITORING OF GRANTEES. The Secretary monitors grantees to ensure compliance with the Act, with the authority to withhold, terminate, or recapture funds if not used according to requirements. Grantees must provide access to records for examination upon request. The Secretary can withhold, terminate, or recapture funds if not used as required. Complaints of misuse must be addressed promptly. SEC. 8. REPORTS AND AUDITS.

Grantees must submit reports to the Secretary within 3 months of grant termination. The Secretary will conduct annual audits on grant expenditures. Audits will be independent and follow auditing standards. SEC. 9. EVALUATIONS. The Secretary will contract an independent research organization to evaluate demonstration projects under the Act, focusing on participant involvement and effectiveness in preventing violent crime and drug trafficking in target communities. The Secretary will allocate 1-3% of funds for evaluations of projects aimed at preventing violent crime and drug trafficking in target communities. A report to Congress is due within 6 months of the last grant termination. The Secretary will prepare and submit a summary of each evaluation conducted under this Act to Congress after the last grant termination. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1997 to 2000. Definitions are provided in Section 11. The Act defines key terms such as "community," "drug trafficking," "economic development," "grantee," and "project participant." The Act defines key terms such as "community," "drug trafficking," "economic development," "grantee," and "project participant." A qualified entity is a non-profit organization exempt from taxation. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. "Violent crime" is defined as a "crime of violence" in title 18 of the United States Code.
